title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | SB 1.17.16-17 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 22-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjan Shalakaya Chaksharun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and Lord Krishna.

segments.key_quote: It gives us a clue as to how we can protect ourselves against the evil influence of Kali, this age, this time.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of discussion: verses 16 and 17 of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on how Parikshit Maharaj dealt with Kali Yuga and how individuals can protect themselves from its negative influences by leading a pious life.

segments.key_quote: The supreme duty of the ruling king is to give all protection to law-abiding persons and to chastise those who stray from the ordinances of the scriptures in ordinary times when there is no emergency.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of the 16th verse, emphasizing the king's duty to protect those who follow religious principles and punish those who deviate, while also discussing the concept of 'apadharma' or occupational duty in times of emergency, using the example of Vishwamitra.

segments.key_quote: When plenty of fruits, vegetables, grains, milk is available, then why should people eat flesh?
segments.summary: The lecture condemns unnecessary animal slaughter and flesh-eating, stating that it is sinful and punishable, especially when other food sources are readily available, emphasizing that one should not kill animals simply to satisfy the tongue.

segments.key_quote: The state executive head is to see that such Swadharma is not changed by the follower, whatever it may be, and he should be given all protection.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the concept of 'Swadharma' or prescribed duty according to one's nature, referencing Bhagavad Gita 18.48, and emphasizes that the state should protect individuals in following their prescribed duties, which should not be violated except in emergencies.

segments.key_quote: The duty of the king is to see that everyone strictly follows his occupational duty as prescribed in the scriptures.
segments.summary: The lecture explains that violators of Swadharma are subject to punishment according to the scriptures, drawing an analogy to civil and criminal laws to illustrate the different levels of transgression and the corresponding consequences, emphasizing that Shastras are perfect and given by the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: Captivated by the devotional qualities of the Pandavas, even Lord Krishna, the personality of Godhead, performed duties as a messenger.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 17th verse, where Dharma responds to Parikshit Maharaj, praising him as a worthy descendant of the Pandavas, whose devotional qualities were so captivating that even Lord Krishna served them.

segments.key_quote: He was not falsely proud for a devotee of the Lord is equally as powerful as the Lord or sometimes more powerful by the Lord's grace.
segments.summary: The lecture explains that Parikshit Maharaj's assurances are not exaggerations but reflect his real power as a devotee of the Lord, emphasizing that devotees can be as powerful as or even more powerful than the Lord by His grace.

segments.key_quote: Pandavas, by their unalloyed devotional service, made it possible for the Lord to become a chariot driver or sometimes their letter messenger.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how the Pandavas' pure devotional service allowed Krishna to become their servant, acting as a chariot driver and messenger, highlighting the Lord's desire to serve His unalloyed devotees.

segments.key_quote: So when Pariksit makes an assurance, it is always backed up by the special protection of the Supreme Lord Himself.
segments.summary: The lecture concludes by reiterating that Parikshit Maharaj, as a pure devotee like his grandfather Arjuna, was always protected by Krishna, even from the womb, and that his assurances are backed by the Lord's special protection, ending with gratitude and the Hare Krishna mantra.
